entry.title: GSoC Blog - Week 7
entry.content:
This is my eighth GSoC blog which tells work done this week.

Work Done This Week:

This Week I took a look on almost all the repositories that are in Gtk+ 2 and need a port to Gtk+ 3 and opened 16 new issues in various repositories. I also updated a repository where I keep a track of all Gtk+ 2, view updated list here.

This week I worked on following activities:

  • Agubrowser Activity
  • Dasher Activity
  • Block Party Activity
  • Star Chart Activity
  • SocialCalc Activity
  • Flip Sticks Activity

Agubrowser Activity

Minor Fixes to complete the port of this activity to Gtk+ 3.

Dasher Activity

Minor improvements.

Block Party Activity

Ported activity to Gtk+ 3, found a great tool while working on it, GtkIndpector, I suggest every GTK/Glib/Gnome enthusiast to check it out. It is meant to work like Chrome Developer tools and does it’s job very well. Faced a couple of issue and learned a lot while working on this acitivity. Adding a toolbar to this activiy was a bit of trouble becuase GtkDrawable was loosing it’s Key press event property. Quickfix for this issue issue is to change can_focus flag to True (verified using GtkInspector), but since it was originally designed to to keep away from the Sugar design, Quozl, Ibiam and I decided to keep it the way it is for now.

Star Chart Activity

Repeated Iterations are being made to this activity to take this to a point where it is ready for next release.

SocialCalc Activity

Fixes to complete the port of this activity to Gtk+ 3.

Flip Sticks Activity

This activity was a challenging activity to work on. All it’s code was written in Drawable, so first major work to port it Cairo, being a big activity this task was big in itself. Following this was porting to Gtk+ 3. Port to Gtk+ 3 was successful but Cairo part of this code is still buggy, Quozl has guided me to complete its work.

entry.title: GSoC Blog - Week 5
entry.content:
This is my sixth GSoC blog which tells work done this week.

Work Done This Week:

This week I worked on following activities:

  • Jigsaw Puzzle Activity
  • Star Chart Activity
  • AEIOU Activity
  • Turtle Confusion Activity
  • I Can Read Activity

Jigsaw Puzzle Activity

This is a jigsaw puzzle game activity on which some work was done by Zeeshan Khan who was doing this project last year. His work was half way through and took me couple of days to fix most of the errors that were logged. Latter I came across a issue, which after a hours of searching for a fix, prooved to be a bug in Cairo drawing itself. After discussion with Benjamin Berg from Gnome, who has been also been a contributor to Sugar Labs, found that only way to fix the problem is to refactor the code and avoid using window for each Jigsaw puzzle and use instead use Gtk.Drawing in place of it. This will lead to losing the functionality of mouse click used to drag and drop the jigsaw puzzle. After discussion with mentors, it was decided to defer this activity.

Star Chart Activity

Started my work on this activity and pushed some commits on Gtk3 branch on my fork.

AEIOU Acitivity

All work on this activity was completed and the pull request was merged in the master branch

Turtle Confusion Activity

Work on this Activity still continues. I am making all changes requested by James Cameron to make this commit mergeable.

I Can Read Activity

Spend another day on it, did get some success while fixing. Pull request is now closer to be merged.

entry.title: GSoC Blog - Week 1
entry.content:
This is my second GSoC blog which focuses on the workflow involved to porting a activity to gtk+ 3.

As the world changes, Sugar cannot stand still. If the platforms we depend upon drop support for the version tools we are using, then we have to either take over maintenance of these tools ourselves as proposed, update our work so that it remains compatible. The migration to GTK-3 is critical.

As the project description says “GTK+ 2 and GStreamer 0.10 are end of life. We need to upgrade the remaining activities with these dependencies.”, we need to upgrade the Sugar activities to maintain its support and get security update on various platforms. The movement from PyGTK to PyGObject API means no more maintenance of it. GTK+ 3 is a major new version of GTK+ that breaks both API and ABI compared to GTK+ 2, which has remained API- and ABI-stable for a long time. The main purpose of this project is to port dependencies of 25 Sugar activities from “GTK+ 2 and GStreamer 0.10” to “GTK+ 3 and GStreamer 1.0”. The task will be accompanied by updating to the latest version of sugargame and Sugar Toolkit. GTK+ 3 introduced many changes to improve UI by providing a number of new widgets, switches, toolbars etc. A lot of other changes have also been introduced, to name a few: Use of Cairo for Drawing, Use of GtkBox, Removal of HippoCanvas library and many more.

The import of pygtk should be changed to import gi. All the codes which includes gtk should be replaced by Gtk. And there is no gtk.gdk library maintained by the developers so you should replace gtk.gdk with Gdk. All the imports should be changed from import gtk to from gi.repository import Gtk. All the imports from sugar should be changed to sugar3. As sugar3 toolkit is based on Gtk3 and sugar toolkit was based on gtk2 so Use sugar3 toolkit.

For example :

– import pygtk
– pygtk.require(‘2.0‘)
– import gtk
– from sugar.graphics import style

should be replaced by :

+ import gi
+ gi.require_version(“Gtk“, “3.0“)
+ from gi.repository import Gdk
+ from gi.repository import Gtk
+ from sugar3.graphics import style

Hbox, Vbox, pack_start, pack_end : This method pack_start, end takes 4 parameters :

  • widget to pack
  • expand
  • fill
  • padding

Earlier in pygtk it was optional to specify every parameter. If not specified default values were used. But in Gtk3 it is complusory to specify all the 4 parameters. So while porting to Gtk3 if a parameter is not specified in pygtk you can add that parameter and put the default value to it.

  • If expand was not set, use value True
  • If fill was not set, use value True.
  • If padding was not set, use value 0.

For example : – box.pack_start(widget, True, False) Should be changed to : + box.pack_start(widget, expand=True, fill=False, padding=4)

A great guide for porting to gtk+ 3 can be found in sugar-docs.

entry.title: GSoC’ 18 with Sugar Labs
entry.content:
Wohoo! I have been selected in Google Summer of Code 2018.

I am very excited to work with Sugar Labs this summer on ‘Say no to GTK+ 2’ project. Thanks to GSoC, Google and Sugar Labs for providing me such a great opportunity.

The proposal for the project can be found here

Sugar Labs® is a volunteer-driven member project of Software Freedom Conservancy, a nonprofit corporation. Originally part of the One Laptop Per Child project, Sugar Labs coordinates volunteers around the world who are passionate about providing educational opportunities to children through the Sugar Learning Platform.

Project:

Just say no to GTK+ 2

As the world changes, Sugar cannot stand still. If the platforms we depend upon drop support for the version tools we are using, then we have to update our work so that it remains compatible.

With the end of GTK+ 2 and GStreamer 0.10, we need to upgrade the activities with these dependencies. The purpose of this project is to port dependencies of 25 Sugar activities to “GTK+ 3 and GStreamer 1.0”. The task is accompanied by updating to the latest version of sugargame and Sugar Toolkit. This project ensures better performance and long-term support for these sugar activities. My Mentors:

Carlos Mauro Cardenas

Ignacio Rodriguez

Chihurumnaya Ibiam

Work Done:

I was one of the early birds who started contributing in December. I had made a total of 71 commits before the submission of proposal. Here is the list of all my commits. Most of my work was based on ‘porting to GTK+ 3’ (which is also my GSoC project) and fixing bugs on Sugar Activities. Task for Next Week:

I will be writing a detailed workflow for porting sugar activities from GTK+2 to GTK+ 3. It will follow some trivial steps that I will follow during porting of each activity.

Looking forward to an amazing summer. cheers!
entry.summary: Wohoo! I have been selected in Google Summer of Code 2018.
